content.text: The ampere, metre and second are SI base units
State **two** other SI base units
The average drift speed \(\nu\) of electrons moving through a metal conductor is given by the equation:
where \(e\) is the charge on an electron
\(F\) is a force acting on the electron
and \(\mu\) is a constant
Determine the SI base units of \(\mu\)
SI base units   .........
displacement
acceleration
Define:
With reference to the motion of the man, state and explain whether he is in equilibrium
Show that the difference in height \(h\) between points A and B is \(3200 \text{m}\)
For the movement of the man from A to B, determine:
1. the decrease in gravitational potential energy
decrease in gravitational potential energy =   .........  J
2. the magnitude of the force on the man due to air resistance
The pressure of the still air at A is \(63\mathrm{kPa}\) and at B is \(92\mathrm{kPa}\). Assume the density of the air is constant between A and B
Determine the density of the air between A and B
density =   .........  \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{-3}\)
A man wearing a wingsuit glides through the air with a constant velocity of \(47 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(24^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The path of the man is shown in Fig. 2.1
The total mass of the man and the wingsuit is \(85\mathrm{kg}\). The man takes a time of 2.8 minutes to glide from point A to point B
By considering the components of momentum in the direction from A to B, show that ball X has a mass of \(4.0 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the common speed \(V\) of the two balls after the collision
Determine the difference between the initial kinetic energy of ball X and the initial kinetic energy of ball Y
difference in kinetic energy =   .........  J
Two balls, X and Y, move along a horizontal frictionless surface, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1

Ball X has an initial velocity of \(3.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) in a direction along line AB. Ball Y has a mass of \(2.5 \text{kg}\) and an initial velocity of \(9.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\) in a direction at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to line AB
The two balls collide at point B. The balls stick together and then travel along the horizontal surface in a direction at right-angles to the line AB, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Define electric field strength

Sphere X has a charge of \(+3e\) and sphere Y has a charge of \(-3e\), where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The rod is held at its mid point Z at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal. The rod and spheres have negligible mass and are in a uniform electric field. The electric field strength is \(5.0 \times 10^{4} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\). The direction of this field is vertically upwards
The electric field is produced by applying a potential difference of \(4.0 \text{kV}\) between two charged parallel metal plates
1. Calculate the separation between the plates
separation =   .........  m
Determine the magnitude and direction of the force on sphere Y
magnitude =   .........  N
direction
The electric forces acting on the two spheres form a couple. This couple acts on the rod with a torque of \(6.2 \times 10^{-16} \text{Nm}\)
Calculate the angle \(\theta\) of the rod to the horizontal
Two very small metal spheres X and Y are connected by an insulating rod of length \(72 \text{mm}\). A side view of this arrangement is shown in Fig. 4.1
the principle of superposition
what is meant by coherence
By reference to two waves, state:

Two coherent waves P and Q meet at a point in phase and superpose. Wave P has an amplitude of \(1.5 \text{cm}\) and intensity \(I\). The resultant intensity at the point where the waves meet is \(3I\)
Calculate the amplitude of wave Q
amplitude =   .........  \(cm\)

1. the current in resistor Z
current =   .........  A
2. the total power provided by the battery
The resistance \(R_{\chi}\) is now decreased
State and explain the change, if any, to the reading on the voltmeter
A battery of e.m.f. 6.0V and negligible internal resistance is connected to a network of resistors and a voltmeter, as shown in Fig. 6.1
Resistor Y has a resistance of \(24\Omega\) and resistor Z has a resistance of \(32\Omega .\)
are not fundamental
do not experience an electric force when situated in an electric field
has the largest ratio of charge to mass
The names of four particles are listed below
alpha beta-plus neutron proton
State the name(s) of the particle(s) in this list that:

A hadron has a charge of \(+e\) where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The hadron is composed of only two quarks. One of these quarks is an antidown \((\bar{\mathsf{d}})\) quark. By considering charge, state and explain the name (flavour) of the other quark
